turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Find it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Whether --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: The Court on re-hearing said this.
“She refused to vacate, charging her lease was being vacated because of her having been elected president of the parent's club.
No evidence was offered as to the purposes of the club, nor that its activities conflicted with interest to their authority.

The manager of the authority stated unequivocally, under oath, that the termination of the lease had no connection whatever with the tenant's activities and get back to the parents club, Judge Picket so found.
That was the Trial Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, where did Judge Picket so find?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: In the Superior Court judgment which -- in this appendix here, that was upon --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that language that I just read?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that page 28?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: The language that you just read was one of the findings it is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On page 21?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: 21, finding number 10 says this is the finding of the Court below that the plaintiff, Housing Authority to the City of Durham, acting through C.S. Oldham, its Manager and Executive Director, gave notice to the defendant to vacate said premises, not because she had engaged in efforts to organize the tenants of McDougald Terrace nor because she was elected president of a group organizing McDougald Terrace on August 10, 1965 that these were not the reason the said notice was given and eviction undertaken.
That was the finding of the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's the finding, but the judgment says that's immaterial.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It makes no difference.
It makes no difference if the term has expired.
She's there illegally.

It is immaterial, and I'm reading from page 28, it is immaterial what may have been the reason for the lessor's unwillingness to continue the relationship of landlord and tenant after the expiration of the term that's provided in the lease.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That, of course, if Your Honor please, is not the opinion or not the judgment in the Trial Court.
That is the per curiam opinion of the Supreme Court of North Carolina as it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: As it appeared when the case was first heard in that Supreme Court, but what I'm saying is that when it went back to the Supreme Court of North Carolina, they added --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you mean on our remand?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: On your remand, yes, sir.
They said a different -- or not necessarily a different thing, but they amplified what their meaning was.

I -- when we're here before, my contention was that this language in this per curiam decision, not only that it was immaterial, under the showing in the evidence that was presented there, what their reason might have been because there was no showing of any constitutional violation by the petitioner.
For that reason, it became immaterial but there was no holding even then that she could not have the opportunity to show that any constitutional right was violated.

Then, when it went back to the Supreme Court of Carolina on re-hearing, the Court went further into that particular point of the finding -- on the finding that her First Amendment rights had not been violated by the Trial Court and then said that since they were based on competent evidence, those findings by the trial judge which appear in finding number 10 should be sustained.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask you a question?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, could I finish this just once?
What is the finding in Murrill versus Palmer, 164 North Carolina, which is cited by the Supreme Court for its statement that I just read about the immateriality for the reason for the ejection?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That was just ordinary landlord-tenant situation in which notice was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And what did they hold there?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That the -- that no constitutional issue was raised in that case.
They just gave them notice and the -- it was a normal eviction proceeding.
No governmental agency was involved in that case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And on the authority of that case, they said here that it is immaterial what the reason was.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Well, I don't think that when they say it's immaterial in that first per curiam decision, they are really staking out what the Court's view of the matter was.
This was not the Trial Court.
It'd be the Supreme Court of North Carolina per curiam decision in one summons says that, “Under the findings that have come to us.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, it doesn't say that.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Well, I'm saying just what it means.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Your -- well, I know That's different.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: All it says is that it's immaterial, but I think that you have to construe what they're talking about in terms of the case that was then before, which was a case that had come before them with a finding of fact by the trial judge that First Amendment rights had not been violated and that there'd been no request by the petitioner for further exploration by the Trial Court into any reasons and there'd been no objection or exception taken to any action by the Trial Court, vice versa, any further exploration or what the reasons might have been.
And, in that context, I take it that, on appeal to the Supreme Court of North Carolina, it really was immaterial what the reasons were.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I thought that the petitioners did take exception to those things?
There relate it here on page --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: They didn't take exceptions --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Exception 1 on page 21 and exception 2 on page 22, and 3 and 4 and 5, I think they --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: The exceptions are on page 25, I think, of the appendix, grouping of exceptions and assignments of error.

And, what I'm saying is that there were no exceptions taken to the scope of the Trial Court's inquiry and the reasons because there was no request made upon the Trial Court to broaden the scope of its inquiry.
Therefore, there would -- could be no exception taken to the Trial Court just confining itself to the evidence presented by the petitioner.
And, her contentions, she said they were in the trial.
There was no request to the judge and the trial of the action say “Make them come in and give us additional reasons.”
They didn't ask that, and the fact that he didn't do it on his own motion was not accepted, too, either there.

When it went from the Trial Court to the Supreme Court, they didn't take exceptions to the failure of the Trial Court on its own motion to make further inquiry and broaden the scope of its inquiry and the reasons for the eviction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if the North Carolina Court did have that attitude that it's immaterial, I suppose you would concede they may be in error.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think this language at least --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or you would say that --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Is an error.
If that language is literal --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or at least if the state refuses to make some form available to enforce constitutional rights, there's bound to be some form somewhere then.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That is correct, but I think that what you're confronted with here is, you have the same thing, as far as evidence and findings are concerned, is that before the Supreme Court of Carolina and you say that, on the basis of those findings and on that evidence, she had a fair trial in the Trial Court there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if you -- what if the Court here didn't agree with you that the circular was maybe we call it retroactive or not, at least here, here came a circular from HUD before this case was finally disposed of.
It was on appeal here or somewhere when the circular came out.
Now, why shouldn't the circular apply the law announced by that circular if it is the law and binding?
Let's just assume that it is.
Why shouldn't that law determine the appeal?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: If It's --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or why shouldn't the appeal be determined in Court?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: If it's in terms --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would be the normal rule, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: It would be within the context of the generally applicable rules.
I think this Court has applied to other situations in which you have a procedural rule that has entered into the picture between the trial and the final determination you apply whatever.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you -- if the Court thought this circular was to be applied to pending cases, then what?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: We just lost the lawsuit, I gather.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But do you think it's binding?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I don't think it's binding.
I think it's --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do we have to determine that here?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think you have here a contractual situation.
You have a state agency to be sure, but it's not a federal agency.

The local Housing Authority is created under a state statute, and HUD doesn't have a vestige of authority over it granted by any statute except by virtue of entering into an annual contributions contract with it and the sign on the dotted line, HUD and the local Authority.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I take it then, you must get down to this really because you seem to concede the general rule would be that if this is a binding rule of some kind, it really ought to apply to pending cases.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so, your real last resort is whether it's really binding on it, on a local agency, whether this kind of circular really determines -- is supposed to determine your conduct.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you suggest that you can -- may depart from it now, although you're complying with it now, you can depart from it without violating any kind of Federal Law.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think so.

I think that because you'd have to be very careful about reviewing the content of the annual contributions contract, which we have done and can find nothing in it that gives HUD the prerogative under the terms of that contract to say what kind of lease we're going to have, whether it should be for six months, one month, one year, or anything like that and it doesn't give them any prerogative to say that you must have an administrative hearing in advance of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Isn't that the real issue between you and Mr. Nabris?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That's correct.
It's whether the constitution of this country requires that there'd be an administrative hearing or administrative giving of reasons before the eviction proceedings --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Before you go to Court.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Before we go to Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Mr. could I follow up one question?

Assuming that your view is deceptive on that problem, what -- I'm not quite sure that I understand your view as to what would be your position if, in an administrative -- in any summary eviction proceedings that I cannot be evicted because I have received no reasons for my eviction period, what would happen on that part?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I would say that would not be a sufficient defense on the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Not a sufficient defense?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That's right.
I cannot be evicted because I received no reason.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Right, and then, suppose that she said “I want to prove my answer to the questions of the majority that I was evicted because I was a Negro.”

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think she would've been entitled to do so.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But she has to make that assertion as a matter of speculation or suspicion, however we feel about her, knew well about her, she cannot explore as to what the reasons have been?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: I think she could.
I think she could insist upon her right to examine the agen -- the executive director of the authority.
If he got up on the stand and ask “What reason did you have?”

He might say “I had no reason at all, I just wanted a vacant apartment there,” but we say, constitutionally, he would be entitled -- that would be a constitutionally acceptable answer and said “I had no reason at all, I just wanted a vacant apartment.”

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And, as Justice White suggested, the language in here must have been that North Carolina was a little overbroad.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That was the first -- the first opinion was overbroad and I concede that it was, and I don't think that the language accurately portrayed what the Court was thinking and what it was holding.
I know it didn't portray what it was actually holding on the basis of the record before it.
And then, when it went back on re-hearing, I think it clarified that point.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: So, she would get a chance.
She would have a right to get the reasons for the eviction?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: A case that much?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Ed --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, I didn't understand that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where?
In the Courts?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: In the Courts.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, what if --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That is the issue between you.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, that has been denied up to now.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, that's right.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: She never -- she has never asked in the Trial Court, if Your Honor please, what the reasons were.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Now, you're being technical.
In North Carolina she's asked.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: No, sir.
She did not ask in the trial of this action.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: She asked in the Supreme Court of North Carolina.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: They should -- There was no evidence, of course, in the Supreme Court, but when an opportunity during the trial --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: The tenant -- the point is a point to be decided.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: But when the action was tried, when the matter was before the Trial Court on finding the issues, the Trial Court found on her and she contended that her First Amendment right had been violated.
Evidence was introduced on that point.
The Court found against her.
There was no additional question asked about what the reasons were in that trial of that action.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: On the discover proceedings in these procedures?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This procedure and let's see, this is the kind of case that goes --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Discover procee --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The summary eviction proceeding is in what Court?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Superior Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And, in that Court, are there discovery proceedings?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: There are indeed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And when she was served, it was possible to have asked the question what was the reason, was there any reason, and so forth?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: She could've had pre-trial discovery by interrogatories, written interrogatories or by pre-trial examinations of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Doesn't this start before the Justice of the Peace really?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Sorry?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This starts really before the Justice of the Peace.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: It starts before the Justice of the Peace.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then it's --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: It's de novo.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then it's de novo in the Superior Court.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Completely de novo.
It's just like starting all over again.
She filed in lieu of pleadings and affidavits setting out what her contentions were about why she was being --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is there a pre-trial proceeding, as well as pre-trial discovery available under your thrust?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Pre-trial discovery, yes.
But, in an eviction proceeding, the normal course is before a justice and then it goes to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So you don't really get to discovery proceedings, I guess.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: You can't.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You get to the Superior Court?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Until she appeals from the justice --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: And then she gets into it, but it's de novo, completely new in the Superior Court and, before you get to that stage, she does have the discovery proceedings available.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well I take it that the -- somewhere, I remember reading in here, that the -- one of the officials of the Housing Authority actually appears in Court before the Justice of the Peace.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then there was a stipulation about what his testimony would be --

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In the Superior Court.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, although they didn't need to sign that stipulation, they could've had him there.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: They could've had him there and they could've cross-examined him and ask him any number of questions, at least as far as this record is concerned they could've, because there was no question that they asked that was denied by the Court, there's no ruling of irrelevancy anywhere along the line by the Trial Court, and they made no exception.
They didn't ask the Trial Court, “now, will you expand this hearing in this Trial Court to require into other reasons that might have existed?”
They didn't ask that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The Court said it was immaterial, didn't it?

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: No, sir.
The Trial Court did not.
It was never said in the Trial Court that it was immaterial at any stage because the question was never asked in the Trial Court, never.
It was only the language, that Your Honor was referring to, appears for the first time in the per curiam deci -- opinion of the Supreme Court of North Carolina.
That's the only place that that sentence has ever appeared in this whole lawsuit, from the beginning to the end.
That's the one place it's appeared.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the sentence at least has created a confusion.

turn.speaker: daniel_k_edwards
turn.label: Mr. Daniel K. Edwards
turn.text: It has created a confusion, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess now.
